data.text: www.americanradiohistory.com , , ISSUE NUMBER 1011 THE INDUSTRY'S NEWSPAPER SEPTEMBER 24, 1993 INS /DE: 10 TIPS TO HELP A NEW TALK HOST BECOME A SUCCESS Without the proper management support and work atmosphere, even the most talented new talk host is vulnerable to failure. KFAN & KEEY /Minneapolis OM Lorna Gladstone offers 10 suggestions to ensure a successful launch. Page 35 COUNTRY, UC: STRONG SPRING SCOREBOARDS Country radio listening among adults 25 -54 hit a record high in the Spring '93 Arbitron, and nearly 60% of Urban stations either improved or maintained their 12+ numbers. Pages 36, 31 CHR PROGRAMMERS DISCUSS THE ART OF DAYPARTING WDJX/Louisville's Chris Shebel and KUBE/Seattle's Bob Case explain why and how they daypart, while WKHUOcean City's Jack Da Wack tells why he doesn't. Page 30 NEW ROCK KRZQ INTO CONCERT PROMOTION Faced with a lack of concerts coming through town, KRZQ/ Reno entered the concert promotion arena itself. PD Rob "Blaze" Brooks details the logistics. IN THE NEWS... Charlie Seraphin to VP /GM at KRLD /Dallas Rick Stacy new PD at KKFR /Phoenix Steve Martorano named Dir. /Ops at WMMR /Philly Steve Bartels becomes Page 33 Arista VP /Special Projects Newsstand Price $8.00 Page 3 Radio Station Staffing Off 7% LMAs/duopolies hit support jobs hardest Employment levels at radio stations appear to have fallen 7% over the last year, according to preliminary results of a Miller, Kaplan, Arase & Co. salary survey conducted over the summer. The loss of jobs can be attributed probably in part to cost - cutting by station operators, but it's likely that many jobs were also eliminated as a result of LMA and duopoly consolidations. In R &R's annual Management /Sales survey, also conducted over the summer, more than 14% of the responding stations were involved in an LMA or duopoly operation, up 5% from last year. STAFFING /See Page 25 4$ Cox Ignites '70s Format In Tampa Cox Broadcasting joined the '70s music bandwagon with the unveiling of `Coast 107.3 . . The greatest hits of the '70s - all the time:' It debuted at noon Tuesday (9/21). The new station occupies the dial position formerly held by Cox AC WWRM, which was moved to 94.9. Cox is operating Coast (formerly AOR WYNF) via an LMA with CBS, pending approval of its purchase. It will switch calls to WCOF ("The Coast of Florida') and is looking for a PD /air talent who will report to WWRM, WSUN, & WYNF OM Toni Palaveda. Prerecorded liners and jingles are being incorporated, but the '70s -based format is currently running without live announcers. WYNF, however, hopes to add personalities when a PD is hired. After logging nearly 100 curious phone calls, the Jet City rocker unveiled the breakthough version, smashing the sound barrier in the form of a classic 1960 sunburst Les Paul. ;. Video Choices To Explode In '94 The number of video music channels will at least double during the next year. And one of them will be operated by a major record company. This week, BMG announced a joint venture with cable TV mega -giant TCI to create a music video channel that will also offer music industry news and sell merchandise. The project begins its rollout next year. More new cable TV music services are also on tap: Black Entertainment Television will launch "BET On Jazz: The Cable Jazz Channel" next year. The ad- supported service will air music videos, in- studio performances, jazz festivals, live performances, and documentaries. MTV is set to split into three channels next year. The network is still mum on its plans, but format-specific channels and an interactive service are reportedly being discussed. The Box, which currently operates its interactive pay -perview programming on local cable systems, announced a na- tional interactive service. Additional channels are also expected. 500- Channel Access The surge in music video channels - as well as other types of programming - is in response to a technological rev - VIDEO /See Page 25 Quarterly Label Performance Review Page 26
